awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The GOGREEN Survey - Caring about the Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
The team will use ground-based telescopes to study the vast population of "satellite" galaxies that live in the suburbs of cities of galaxies called clusters. We know that satellite galaxies can transform themselves from bluish systems rife with brilliant, young stars into reddish systems filled with dull, old stars. But models that attempt explain this remarkable transformation fail dismally. This means that the modellers need much more guidance about factors that govern a galaxy's life in the suburbs. The team will provide that important guidance. The team will also expand existing, successful outreach programs at their institutions. Areas of emphasis include high school students using the new data to conduct inquiry-based research, school teachers adding evidence-based research into their lesson plans, deaf students "smelling" and "touching" data that have been suitably transformed, and Hispanic students being encouraged to continue on from college to graduate school.

The aim of the project is to examine the physical processes responsible for quenching the star formation in clusters' satellite galaxies, as distinct from their central galaxies. Models of central-galaxy quenching agree well with observations. In contrast, models of satellite-galaxy quenching strongly violate observations, meaning that such models need better guidance about the processes involved. The team will provide that guidance by obtaining new spectroscopic data for massive groups and clusters at redshifts of 1-1.5 and comparing those data to existing lower-redshift data. These comparisons will be used to analyze the dominant modes of satellite quenching, how galaxies populate dark-matter halos as a function of environment, the relative timing of morphological transformation and star-formation quenching, and the dominant driver of size growth in quenched galaxies. These results will lead to new, better-informed models of satellite-galaxy quenching.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The Gemini Observations of Galaxies in Rich Early ENvironments (GOGREEN) Survey was successfully completed, producing the premier spectroscopic and photometric dataset for galaxy clusters at z > 1. In addition to characterizing and releasing the dataset to the public, the PI and collaborators conducted a wide range of analyses related to the properties of cluster galaxies as a function of cosmic time. In particular, analysis of the GOGREEN sample showed that the suppression of star formation in satellite galaxies at intermediate redshift proceeds quickly (< 2 Gyr), following infall, with starvation being the most likely mechanism responsible for quenching. Currently, hydrodynamic simulations of galaxy formation fail to reproduce the dependence of quenching efficiency on satellite mass at intermediate redshift, with the GOGREEN dataset providing an important benchmark for future work on the development of modeling efforts. In total, this award supported research efforts that yielded >20 peer-reviewed publications. As part of the Cal-Bridge Program, the PI also worked to improve the representation of URMs in STEM fields, particularly physics and astronomy. To date, Cal-Bridge has supported and mentored >100 undergraduate scholars, with the majority continuing on to pursue graduate degrees. The PI also worked tirelessly to support students within the Department of Physics & Astronomy at the University of California Irvine (UCI), including efforts to provide equitable and timely support for graduate students during the early part of the Covid-19 pandemic. These broader impact efforts at UCI also included significant time devoted to addressing issues of equity and inclusion created by the failures of leadership within the University and the faculty of the Department of Physics & Astronomy.


Last Modified: 05/17/2022
Modified by: Michael Cooper
